p: Liudong Xing received her B.E. degree in Computer Science from Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China, in 1996, and became a graduate research assistant in Shenyang Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Science, China from 1996 to 1998. She was awarded the M.S. and Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of Virginia, Charlottesville, in 2000 and 2002, respectively. Dr. Xing is currently an Assistant Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth. Her major research interests lie in the design and analysis of dependable computer-based systems and networks. She is a member of IEEE.

authors.name: Liudong Xing

p: Joanne Bechta Dugan was awarded the B.A. degree in Mathematics and Computer Science from La Salle University, Philadelphia, PA in 1980, and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from Duke University, Durham, NC in 1982 and 1984, respectively. Dr. Dugan is currently Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Virginia. She has performed and directed research on the development and application of techniques for the analysis of computer systems which are designed to tolerate hardware and software faults. Her research interests thus include hardware and software reliability engineering, fault tolerant computing, and mathematical modeling using dynamic fault trees, Markov models, Petri nets and simulation. Dr. Dugan is an IEEE Fellow, was Associate Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Reliability for 10 years, and is currently Associate Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering. She served on the National Research Council Committee on Application of Digital Instrumentation and Control Systems to Nuclear Power Plant Operations and Safety.

references.title: A BDD-based algorithm for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems

context.text: IN [2], Zang, Sun, & Trivedi presented an algorithm for solving phased-mission systems (PMS) using binary decision diagrams (BDD).
The phase dependent operation (PDO) presented in [2], Section 3.1 is used to combine single-phase BDD to obtain the entire PMS BDD.

Specifically, when we combine two single-phase BDD whose root nodes belong to the same component but to different phases, the PDO will be applied to the combination instead of the ordinary BDD operation ([2], Section 3.1), so that the \$s\$-dependency existing between the variables of the same component but different phases can be addressed during the process of combination.

However, the PDO developed in [2], Section 3.1 can generate the correct PMS BDD only given that the ordering scheme abides by the following rules:

•Rule 1: Orderings adopted in the generation of each single-phase BDD are consistent or the same for all the phases.
•Rule 2: Orderings of variables that belong to the same component but to different phases stay together, which is achieved by replacing each component indicator-variable with a set of variables which represent this component in each phase after ordering components using heuristics ([2], Section 3.1).
Otherwise, that is, if either of the above rules is violated, the PDO presented in [2], Section 3.1 won't be complete or enough to fulfill the task of combining single-phase BDD to generate PMS BDD.

In other words, using the PDO of [2], Section 3.1, plus an arbitrary variable ordering that is not necessarily consistent with the above stated rules, may produce incorrect overall PMS BDD for reliability evaluation, as illustrated using examples presently.
These rules are implied in [2], Section 3.1, but not explicitly stated.

Rule 2: Orderings of variables that belong to the same component but to different phases stay together, which is achieved by replacing each component indicator-variable with a set of variables which represent this component in each phase after ordering components using heuristics ([2], Section 3.2).

If a backward PDO [2] is adopted, then either of two kinds of typical ordering strategies for generating the PMS BDD can be used in the practical implementation:

•Order 1: Variables of the same component stay together: \$a_{2} \prec a_{1} \prec b_{2} \prec b_{1} \prec c_{2} \prec c_{1} \prec d_{2}\prec d_{1}\$.
Applying the backward PDO as defined in [2], we can generate the PMS BDD from single-phase BDD for the Order 1 & Order 2, as shown in Fig. 3(a) and (b), respectively.
PMS BDD generated by the PDO in [2] using the ordering of \$a_{2} \prec b_{2} \prec c_{2} \prec d_{2} \prec d_{1} \prec c_{1} \prec b_{1} \prec a_{1}\$.
In other words, the rules of variable ordering for PDO to generate the correct PMS BDD in [2] are too limiting.
In summary, for any arbitrary backward (or forward) PDO ordering, only the PDO presented in [2] is not enough to generate a correct PMS BDD from the single-phase BDD.
However, the PDO of [2], supplemented by the removal process discussed in these comments, can generate the correct final PMS BDD.
The correct PDO algorithm is given by the original algorithm for the PDO ([2]), followed by a removal process described by the following recursive algorithm:.
\${\tt\rm R} = {\tt\rm the~root~mode~of~the~PMS~BDD}{\tt\rm ~generated~by~the~original~PDO~algorithm~in~Table~A~in}\$ [2];.
The definition of the ite operator can be found in [1], [2].
This paper proposes a method to improve the BDD-based algorithm for reliability analysis of PMS in [2] by allowing any arbitrary ordering strategy to be used for generating PMS BDD.
The PDO operations of [2] can deal with the \$s\$-dependencies thoroughly, and generate the correct PMS BDD for reliability evaluation, given the specific order of [2] is used.

links.abstract: This paper presents a new algorithm (PMS-BDD) based on the binary decision diagram (BDD) for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems (PMS). PMS-BDD uses phase algebra to deal with the dependence across the phases, and a new BDD operation to incorporate the phase algebra.
